questions.title: Passage I
questions.article:
Since 1880, Earth's average surface temperature has increased by 0.5°C. This global warming has caused ocean surface temperature increases and the melting of parts of the polar ice caps. Two scientists discuss the cause of these events.

Scientist 1
Global warming is caused by human activities that have significantly increased the atmospheric concentration of CO2 above the concentration prior to 1880. CO2 is one of several greenhouse gases (gases that trap heat emitted from Earth's surface). Human activities, primarily the burning of fossil fuels, have added significant additional CO2 to the air (6 billion tons per year at present). This has increased the atmospheric CO2 concentration by 30% since 1880. The higher the atmospheric CO2 concentration, the warmer Earth's average surface temperature. While atmospheric CO2 concentrations have been steadily increasing over the past 18,000 years, the annual rate of increase over the past 100 years has been 10 to 100 times faster than the rate of increase prior to 1880. Eight of the warmest years on record have occurred since 1979.

Scientist 2
Changes in atmospheric CO2 concentration have little or no effect on average surface temperature. Global warming is caused by an increase in the energy output of the Sun and by regular changes in the shape of Earth's orbit. A less elliptical orbit corresponds to a warmer climate. These 2 factors explain at least 80% of the observed surface temperature increase. The rest can be explained by decreases in the amount of atmospheric sulfate aerosols and increases in the stratospheric ozone content. The 6 billion tons/yr of CO2 from human activities is a very small proportion of the total 186 billion tons/yr of CO2 that enter the atmosphere. Studies of climate records over hundreds of thousands of years show that average surface temperature has increased and decreased in regular cycles that coincide with increases and decreases in solar energy output. This parallel relationship is particularly evident in the steady warming of average surface temperature since the end of the last ice age 18,000 years ago.
questions.question: 1.  If Earth's average surface temperature continues to increase, both Scientist 1 and Scientist 2 would most likely agree that which of the following environmental changes would occur?

choices.A: Earth's polar ice caps would continue to increase in volume.
choices.B: Earth's polar ice caps would continue to decrease in volume.
choices.C: Average ocean temperatures would continue to decrease.
choices.D: Average ocean temperatures would remain constant.

questions.question: 2. If the CO2 input from human activities could be reduced to zero, Scientist 2 would most likely state that this change would have which of the following resulting effects, if any, on global climate? This change would:

choices.A: cause an immediate increase in global temperature.
choices.B: cause an immediate decrease in global temperature.
choices.C: have no effect on the global climate.
choices.D: accelerate the breakdown of the ozone layer.

questions.question: 3.  If Scientist 2 is correct, which of the following graphs would best represent the relationship between solar energy output and Earth's average surface temperature trends over the past 18,000 years?

questions.question: 4. According to the viewpoint of Scientist 1, which of the following graphs best represents the increase in atmospheric CO2 concentration over the past 200 years?

questions.question: 5. Scientist 2 would most likely agree with which of the following statements about the solar energy output 18,000 years ago, at the end of the last ice age? Eighteen thousand years ago, solar energy output was:

choices.C: the same as it is today.

questions.question: 6. Suppose ozone is a greenhouse gas produced by human activities. Scientist 1 would most likely agree that if increases in stratospheric ozone content contribute to the current global warming, these increases do so because ozone:

choices.A: can be changed to oxygen through chemical reactions in the atmosphere.
choices.B: has the ability to trap heat that would otherwise be Iost to space.
choices.C: is the major gaseous component of Earth's atmosphere.
choices.D: has a molecular mass much lower than the molecular mass of CO2.

questions.question: 7.  Scientist 2 would most likely agree that, compared to the amount of CO2, that human activities put into the atmosphere each year, the amount put into the atmosphere each year from sources other than human activities is how many times greater?

choices.C: 20 times greater

questions.title: Passage ll
questions.article:
Crude oil contains thousands of chemical compounds. To obtain commercially useful compounds, crude oil is distilled in a fractionating tower (see Figure 1). The crude oil is first heated to 400°C in a furnace, then pumped into the fractionating tower. As vapors from the oil rise, they cool and condense. Fractions are collected at different heights in the tower. Each fraction contains a mixture 'of hydrocarbon molecules with similar boiling points. Table 1 shows information about some of the fractions that can be collected. Figure 2 shows the composition of crude oils obtained in 6 different geographic locations.



Figure 1 adapted from American Chemical Society, ChemCom: Chemistry in the Community, 2nd ed. ©1993 by American Chemical Society.




Figure 2 adapted from The New Encyclopaedia Britannica. ©1986 by Encyclopaedia Britannica, Inc.
questions.question: 8. According to the information in Table 1, hydrocarbon molecules each having 14 carbon atoms would most likely be found in which of the following fractions?

choices.C: Fuel oil

questions.question: 9. Based on the data in Table 1, a fraction containing a mixture of hydrocarbons ranging in size from 8 to 14 carbon atoms per molecule would most likely have a boiling range:

choices.C: between 100°C and 250°C.

questions.question: 10. Based on the information in Figure 1 and Table 1, a fraction containing a hydrocarbon that has 7 carbon atoms per molecule would most likely be collected:

choices.A: near the top of the fractionating tower.
choices.B: in the middle of the fractionating tower.
choices.C: near the bottom of the fractionating tower.

choices.C: 13 to 18 carbons per molecule.

questions.question: 12.  Is the statement “Oils boiling at temperatures above 340℃ make up the largest proportion of each of the 6 crude oils shown in Figure 2” supported by Figure 2?

choices.A: Yes; oils boiling above 340°C make up more than 20% of the 6 crude oils.
choices.B: Yes; gasoline makes up the smallest proportion of the 6 crude oils.
choices.C: No; oils boiling above 340°C make up the smallest proportion of Crude Oil Sample F.
choices.D: No; gasoline and middle distillates make up more than 70% of Crude Oil Sample A.

questions.title: Passage III
questions.article:
An RC circuit contains a resistor, a capacitor, and an input voltage source. Some students studied RC circuits containing a source of AC (alternating current) voltage. Frequency, in hertz (Hz), is related to the number of times/sec the highest voltage is attained. The measured input voltage from the AC source was the same in Studies 1-3.

Study 1
A circuit was assembled using a 1,000 Ω (ohm) resistor, a 1 microfarad capacitor (microfarad [μF] is a unit of capacitance), 2 voltmeters for measuring output voltages, and an AC input voltage source (see Figure 1).


The students varied the frequency of the input voltage and measured the output voltage, the voltage across the resistor or the capacitor. At each frequency, they calculated the gain, the ratio of the measured output voltage to the measured input voltage. The results are shown in Table 1.

Study 2
The students replaced the 1,000 Ω resistor with a 10,000 Ω resistor and repeated the procedure used in Study 1. The results are shown in Table 2.

Study 3
The students used a 10 μF capacitor and the 10,000 Ω resistor and repeated the procedure used in Study 1. The results are shown in Table 3.
questions.question: 13. In Study 1, the same gain was obtained across the resistor and the capacitor at which, if any, of the frequencies tested?

choices.C: 104 Hz

questions.question: 14. Based on Studies 1 and 2 at 102 Hz, replacing the1,000 Ω resistor with the 10,000 Ω resistor changed the measured output voltage across:

choices.C: both the resistor and the capacitor.
choices.D: neither the resistor nor the capacitor.

choices.C: greater at high frequencies and less at low frequencies.
choices.D: less at high frequencies and greater at low frequencies.

questions.question: 16.  An amplifier produces a measured output voltage that is greater than the measured input voltage. Did the RC circuits used in the 3 studies amplify the input voltage at any of the frequencies tested?

choices.A: Yes, because all of the circuits produced a gain that was greater than 1.0 at one or more frequencies.
choices.B: Yes, because all of the circuits produced a gain that was less than 1.0 at one or more frequencies.
choices.C: No, because none of the circuits produced a gain that was greater than 1.0 at any frequency.
choices.D: No, because none of the circuits produced a gain that was less than 1.0 at any frequency.

questions.question: 18. In Study 1 with the output voltage measured across the resistor, a gain of 0.05 would most likely have been obtained at a frequency between:

choices.C: 102 Hz and 103 Hz.

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Burning household waste in metal barrels can release harmful emissions (airborne gases and particulates), including SO2, CO, NO2, dioxin, lead, and mercury. The remaining ash also may contain toxic substances. Two studies examined these emissions and ash.

Study 1
Two hundred pounds of household waste designated for burning was collected from 12 households. The waste was placed in a metal barrel located under a hood that collected emissions (see Figure 1). The waste was burned for 2 hours at 400°F to 500°F. The average reduction in the weight and the volume of the original waste after burning was 58% and 70%, respectively.


The concentrations of emissions, in parts per million (ppm), were measured. Table 1 shows the results and the established maximum allowed concentrations in emissions from incinerators (facilities that burn large quantities of household waste).

Study 2
The ash from the burned waste in Study 1 was analyzed for the presence of several substances, including mercury and lead. Table 2 shows the measured concentrations in the ash and the established limit that, if exceeded for any one of the substances, means the sample of ash would be considered hazardous.


Figure and tables adapted from Chris Burger, “Emission Characteristics of Burn Barrels.” ©1994 by Patrick Engineering, Inc.
questions.question: 19. Mercury is a liquid at room temperature. Based on the results for mercury in Study 1 and the design of that study, one would conclude which of the following about the properties of mercury? The temperatures of 400°F to 500°F that were reached in the metal barrel were sufficient to change some of the mercury from a:

choices.C: liquid to a solid.

questions.question: 20. The more toxic a substance, the smaller the concentration at which it is considered hazardous. According to this information and Study 1, which of the listed gases is considered the most toxic?

choices.C: NO2

The ash from the burned waste in Study 1 was analyzed for the presence of several substances, including mercury and lead. Table 2 shows the measured concentrations in the ash and the established limit that, if exceeded for any one of the substances, means the sample of ash would be considered hazardous.


Figure and tables adapted from Chris Burger, “Emission Characteristics of Burn Barrels.” ©1994 by Patrick Engineering, Inc.
questions.question: 21. If Study 2 had been repeated using the waste from 15 households instead of 12 households, the resulting measured concentration for each substance in the repeated Study 2 would most likely have been:

choices.A: much higher than the respective concentration in the original study.
choices.B: similar to the respective concentration in the original study.
choices.C: much lower than the respective concentration in the original study.

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:
Burning household waste in metal barrels can release harmful emissions (airborne gases and particulates), including SO2, CO, NO2, dioxin, lead, and mercury. The remaining ash also may contain toxic substances. Two studies examined these emissions and ash.

Study 1
Two hundred pounds of household waste designated for burning was collected from 12 households. The waste was placed in a metal barrel located under a hood that collected emissions (see Figure 1). The waste was burned for 2 hours at 400°F to 500°F. The average reduction in the weight and the volume of the original waste after burning was 58% and 70%, respectively.


The concentrations of emissions, in parts per million (ppm), were measured. Table 1 shows the results and the established maximum allowed concentrations in emissions from incinerators (facilities that burn large quantities of household waste).

Study 2
The ash from the burned waste in Study 1 was analyzed for the presence of several substances, including mercury and lead. Table 2 shows the measured concentrations in the ash and the established limit that, if exceeded for any one of the substances, means the sample of ash would be considered hazardous.


Figure and tables adapted from Chris Burger, “Emission Characteristics of Burn Barrels.” ©1994 by Patrick Engineering, Inc.
questions.question: 22. According to the results of Study 1, which of the following gases emitted from burning waste in metal barrels exceeded the maximum allowed emission concentration set for incinerators?

choices.C: NO2

questions.title: Passage IV

The waste was burned for 2 hours at 400°F to 500°F. The average reduction in the weight and the volume of the original waste after burning was 58% and 70%, respectively.


The concentrations of emissions, in parts per million (ppm), were measured. Table 1 shows the results and the established maximum allowed concentrations in emissions from incinerators (facilities that burn large quantities of household waste).

Study 2
The ash from the burned waste in Study 1 was analyzed for the presence of several substances, including mercury and lead. Table 2 shows the measured concentrations in the ash and the established limit that, if exceeded for any one of the substances, means the sample of ash would be considered hazardous.


Figure and tables adapted from Chris Burger, “Emission Characteristics of Burn Barrels.” ©1994 by Patrick Engineering, Inc.
questions.question: 23. Which of the following statements about the concentrations of substances in the ash from burning waste in metal barrels is supported by the results of Study 2? The ash left after burning waste in metal barrels:

choices.A: contained hazardous concentrations of all the tested substances.
choices.B: contained hazardous concentrations of mercury and lead only.
choices.C: did not contain hazardous concentrations of any of the tested substances.
choices.D: did not contain measurable concentrations of mercury or lead.

questions.title: Passage IV
questions.article:

Study 2

questions.question: 24.  It was hypothesized that burning waste in metal barrels in these studies would produce lower concentrations of particulates than does burning waste in incinerators that comply with established maximum concentrations. Is this hypothesis supported by the results of Study 1?

choices.A: Yes; the average concentration of particulates from burning waste in the metal barrels was lower than the maximum allowed particulate concentration from burning waste in incinerators.
choices.B: Yes; the average concentration of particulates from burning waste in the metal barrels was higher than the maximum allowed particulate concentration from burning waste in incinerators.
choices.C: No; the average concentration of particulates from burning waste in the metal barrels was lower than the maximum allowed particulate concentration from burning waste in incinerators.
choices.D: No; the average concentration of particulates from burning waste in the metal barrels was higher than the maximum allowed particulate concentration from burning waste in incinerators.

questions.title: Passage V
questions.article:
Albert Einstein predicted that light passing by a massive object would be deflected from its original direction of motion (Angle θ in Figure 1).


Einstein also predicted that light's travel time between certain planets would be increased by the Sun's gravity. Experiments 1 and 2 tested Einstein's predictions.

Experiment 1
Einstein predicted that for light of any wavelength skimming the visible edge of the Sun, θ = 1.75 arcsec. To measure θ in visible light (wavelength = 0.00005.cm),scientists observed the stars appearing at the Sun's edge during a total solar eclipse, and they plotted the stars' positions in the sky. Next, they plotted the positions of the same stars when the stars did not appear close to the Sun; θ equaled the angle between the 2 positions of each star. An average of θ was found for all the stars tested. Then, scientists measured and found average values of θ for light at radio wavelengths (3.1 cm and 11.6 cm) skimming the Sun's visible edge.

The results are given in Table 1. (Note: ± signifies the uncertainty in a measurement. For example, at 0.00005 cm, the true value of θ was most likely between 1.57 and 1.87 arcsec.)

Experiment 2
Scientists bounced radio waves off the surface of Venus as Venus moved around the Sun. Figure 2 shows the approximate positions of Venus (V) relative to the Sun(S) and Earth (E) on Days 0, 150, 300, and 450.


The delay measured by the scientists equaled the extra time the radio waves took to make the round trip between Earth and Venus because of the Sun's gravity (see Figure 3).
questions.question: 25. In Experiment 2 on Day 600, the relative positions of the Sun, Earth, and Venus were closet to those shown in which of the following diagrams?

questions.question: 26. According to the uncertainty in the measurement of θ at a wavelength of 3.1 cm, the true value of θ was most likely between:

choices.C: 1.57 arcsec and 1.97 arcsec.

questions.question: 29. During Experiment 2, the largest delay in the radio waves was produced when the radio waves passed:

choices.A: farthest from the edge of the Moon both on their way to the Sun and on their return to Earth.
choices.B: closest to the edge of the Moon both on their way to the Sun and on their return to Earth.
choices.C: farthest from the edge of the Sun both on their way to Venus and on their return to Earth.
choices.D: closest to the edge of the Sun both on their way to Venus and on their return to Earth.

questions.question: 30. The Sun was used in both Experiments 1 and 2 most likely because the Sun:

choices.A: is the brightest object in the solar system.
choices.B: emits both visible light and radio waves.
choices.C: is the most massive body in the solar system.
choices.D: is easily viewed during a solar eclipse.

questions.title: Passage VI
questions.article:
The concentration of dissolved oxygen (DO) in river water affects the fish in the river. Many freshwater fish species, including crappie, perch, and bass, require a minimum average DO concentration of 5 parts per million (ppm) to thrive. Other fish, such as carp and gar, can tolerate average DO concentrations as low as 3 ppm. Table 1 shows the DO concentration at saturation for water at various temperatures. Figures 1 and 2 show the measured changes in a river's water temperature and DO concentration, respectively, over a 24-hour period in midsummer. Table 2 shows how the DO concentration affects fish species in a river.





Table 1 and Figures 1 and 2 adapted from American ChemicalSociety, ChemCom: Chemistry in the Community, 2nd ed. ©1993 by American Chemical Society.
questions.question: 31. River water is often used in industrial processes and is then returned to the river much warmer than when it was removed. Based only on the information inTable 1, why would this warmed water be a potential danger to fish populations? The warmed river water most likely has:

choices.A: a higher DO concentration than does the cooler river water.
choices.B: a lower DO concentration than does the cooler river water.
choices.C: the same DO concentration as does the cooler river water.

questions.title: Passage VII
questions.article:
The male-to-female body mass ratio (MFMR) of a species can be calculated as follows:
MFMR = Mm ÷ Fm

In this equation, Mm is the average body mass of adult males and Fm is the average body mass of adult females.

The figure shows the MFMR of some species within 4 primate groups: apes and humans; Old World monkeys; New World monkeys; and prosimians. A species with an MFMR of 1 is monomorphic with respect to body mass. A species with an MFMR different than 1 is dimorphic with respect to body mass. (Note: In the figure, MFMR values are calculated to the nearest tenth.)
questions.question: 36.  According to the figure, the body mass of the average adult male orangutan is how many times greater than the body mass of the average adult female orangutan?

questions.article:

questions.question: 37. Which of the following statements about the relative size of male and female chimpanzees and aye-ayes is consistent with the information provided?

choices.A: Both chimpanzees and aye-ayes are dimorphic with respect to body mass.
choices.B: Both chimpanzees and aye-ayes are monomorphic with respect to body mass.
choices.C: Chimpanzees are dimorphic with respect to body mass, and aye-ayes are monomorphic with respect to body mass.
choices.D: Chimpanzees are monomorphic with respect to body mass, and aye-ayes are dimorphic with respect to body mass.

questions.question: 40.  Which of the following best explains the units of measure that are associated with the MFMR?

choices.A: The numerator is in units of mass and the denominator is in units of mass, so the ratio has no units.
choices.B: The numerator is in units of mass and the denominator is in units of mass, so the ratio is in units of mass.
choices.C: The numerator is in units of volume and the denominator is in units of volume, so the ratio has no units.
choices.D: The numerator is in units of volume and the denominator is in units of volume, so the ratio is in units of volume.
